en: Purchased in 1925. Formerly in the Peytel Collection.

Nude, white, Eros (labelled), standing on a rocky piece of land (?),
      near profile to the right, bent over to tie his left sandal (drawn in tiny red lines) with
      both hands, with his weight on his slightly bent right leg, his bent left leg raised, with
      frontal, relief gold wings, red/black medium-length, curly hair, ringlets by each ear; tripod
      kanoun, with lion-claw feet, in gold-decorated relief; Pompe (labelled), standing 3/4-view to
      the left, with her head profile to the right, her weight on her right leg, and her left leg
      bent, wearing a purple (?) himation draped around her lower body, held between her knees, and
      veiled up over her back (she holds the top edge in her mouth), over a pink chiton (?), a
      relief grain wreath, a relief beaded necklace, a single bead earring, two relief bands on each
      wrist, and a white anklet on each foot (perhaps denoting the edge of each slipper?), holds an
      untied wreath between both hands, her right hand raised above her shoulder, and her left hand
      just above waist level; Dionysos (said to be labelled) seated 3/4-view to the right, in a
      chair mounted on low platform, with his head turned profile to the left, his right leg pulled
      back, his left leg extended to the right, wearing a himation draped around his lower body, and
      up over his back, slightly protruding over his shoulders, and a relief red ivy wreath, his
      hair tied back, but long ringlets cascading over his shoulder, rests his right arm on the back
      of his klismos, and holds in his upraised left hand an upright thyrsos with a gold
      finial.

<bibl>LIMC</bibl>, 7.435 s.v. Pompe no. 2, pl. 348 (E. Simon);
      <bibl>Robertson 1992</bibl>, 288 fig. 291; <bibl>Valavanis

      rend="ital">BABesch</hi> 20 (1945) 23-25, fig. 25; <bibl>Richter & Hall
      1936</bibl>, 215-16 no. 169, pls. 164, 177 (with previous bibliography).
Pompe (personification of Procession) with Eros and Dionysos
